I searched in the web if an another person had the same problem and I didn't
find anything. For me, it's a mystery

Benoit

I wonder if your upgrade was broken.  Can you please tell me what versions of
these libraries you have installed:

  atk
  pango
  glib
  gtk2

thanks for your answer

I've installed this versions:
atk 1.0
gtk 2.0
glib 2.0*pango 1.4.0

Can you give the specific package versions?  rpm -qa | grep atk (and the same
for the others)?

I give you the answers of these commande lines:

rpm -qa | grep atk:

This is very strange.  The symbol "atk_object_add_relationship" was defined in
atk version 1.2.  You have version 1.6.1 installed, according to the RPM
database.  Are you able to run other GTK+2 applications (gedit, gimp version 2,
any GNOME application)?  Can you try reinstalling the atk library?

I am also confused because a suitable version of atk should have been installed
even with Mandrake 10.0 ...

One thing that's also strange is that you still have the old -devel package for
glib 2.2 even though you have glib 2.4 installed:

  libglib2.0_0-devel-2.2.3-1mdk
  libglib2.0_0-2.4.6-1mdk

It may be worth it to also open a bug at qa.mandrakesoft.com about this issue.

Eclipse worked in the Mandrake 10.0. I've upgraded to the mandrake 10.1 and
after, this problem has occured. I will re-install the atk library and if this
problem  continue, I will open a bug in Mandrake, thank you for your help.
Please post a link here to the Mandrake bug if you open one.

I am going to close this bug now as WORKSFORME.  Please re-open if you think
there is a problem in Eclipse.

Any feedback will be helpful. This is the first time we are trying to use

Cheers and good will.

You're on a Red Hat 8 machine?  I think it's safe to say that this is
an unsupported configuration and that ideally you would upgrade
your version of ATK to 1.2.  I'm reopening the bug to see if maybe
it's easy to avoid using this function if we can detect that you have
ATK 1.0 installed, but I'd hope this is a corner case.  Officially,
we require GTK+ 2.2.1 and its dependencies (which implies at least
ATK 1.2).

Thanks for considering this Billy.

We tried JBuilder 2005 on this platform and it works fine. It would be nice if Eclipse can accomodate such plaforms. We have started using Eclipse on XP and it is just brilliant.

Is the error due to the fact that Eclipse uses SWT ? i.e. it is tied up with the version of the underlying layers it calls upon? I am not sure I fully understand the difference between SWT and Swing but our swing apps work fine on such platforms. JBuilder also uses Swing.

Cheers.

SWT is implemented on Linux using GTK+ 2.  The GTK+ 2.0 series (June 2002)
was the first release series of GTK+ 2 and was rather buggy and did not appear
in many Linux distributions.  Version 2.2 (February 2003) was both more stable
and more prolific, and is used in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 3, their first enterprise
release that provides GTK+ 2.

I suppose we could consider linking to atk_object_add_relationship() dynamically but we're going to just keep breaking you when we call new API that your RH 8 platform doesn't have.  This platform is unsupported and untested.

Your thoughts?  Billy too.

fixed > 0217; note that this is not in the pending 3.2M5 release

While I'm somewhat opposed to this change since the problem's root cause is an invalid user installation, it would be unfortunate for eclipse to not work solely because a user that does not require accessibility facilities does not have the right accessibility library.  atk_object_add_relationship is the only utilized atk function call that is not in atk 1.0 (outside of the accessibility package of course), so this should be the only function that needs a dynamic link.

Is there any plan to have Eclipse officially tested and certified for Fedora releases ? Not all of us use RH Enterprise linux.

It would be helpful to see some Fedora release as part of the supported platforms.

cheers and good will.

Not that I'm aware of, though that does not imply that reports from users of other distributions are not looked into.  For that matter many of the developers here run other distributions on a regular basis.  In most cases though only problems that occur with a valid installation are investigated ;-).

Note that Fedora Linux is not even supported by Red Hat, it's a community-supported
distribution that they basically use to test their enterprise releases.  Experimental
patches have been known to go into Fedora to see what applications break ;)

That said, I think it's reasonable to expect that the Fedora developers wouldn't
intentionally break Eclipse, and that we'll of course make sure we work on Fedora
Linux as much as possible.  However, given the nature of Fedora I do not think
it would be a good idea to "officially" support it.
*** Bug 121717 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
